15 points in a 19 dimensional space (18 variables + 1 for diet group tag), utterly hopeless for anything other then a limited set of predefined set of hypotethis. There isnt even enough points to specify the hyperplane they lie on, which means that almost all types of dataanalysis done after looking at the data is worthless. If your data in arbitary positions cannot overdetermine a hyperplane, then it will always be possible to find some pattern in the result, regardless of whether there existed a pattern in the first place.

You can get around this by only checking for specific patterns (here chocolate makes something better in 1 catagory ), but even then you have to have extra large margin of error when testing multiple hypothetis with one dataset (See Occams razer: P{exists h in H : L(h) >= ^L(h,S) + sqrt(ln(1/(p(h) * delta))/2n) } <= delta, where delta is an arbitary constant, n is the number of data points, h is a hypothethis is the space of hypothesises H, and L(h) is the expected loss of h, ^L(h,S) is the empirical loss of h on dataset S, and p(h) is some distribution over (h) that adds up to 1 when summed over all h in H).

If one runs the numbers, it turns out that he would need an additional 2 standard deviations (roughly, it is not linear) of distance between the low-carb and low-carb+cocholate means to reach the same conclussions that he would have reached otherwise would have, if he only tested on one parameter.
